title: Coif, late 16th–early 17th century
medium:
Medium: linen, silk, metal-wrapped silk-core threads
Technique: embroidered using running, seeding (speckling), stem and couching stitches on plain weave
creditline: Bequest of Richard Cranch Greenleaf in memory of his mother, Adeline Emma Greenleaf
description: Woman's off-white linen coif, with a point over the forehead, shaped at the cheek, and with a pleated detail at the crown. Embroidered in black silks and gold in a pattern of scrolling branches framing flower and fruit clusters among which birds, butterflies, snails and rabbits appear.

exhibitions.title: The Cooper-Hewitt Collections: A Design Resource

tombstone.epitaph:
Coif, late 16th–early 17th century.
late 16th–early 17th century. Medium: linen, silk, metal-wrapped silk-core threads
Technique: embroidered using running, seeding (speckling), stem and couching stitches on plain weave. Bequest of Richard Cranch Greenleaf in memory of his mother, Adeline Emma Greenleaf. 1962-53-3.
